bioghist.p: James H. Smylie (b. 1925) was ordained in 1949 and taught at Princeton from 1950 to 1962. He is Ernest T. Thompson Professor of Church History, Emeritus, at Union Theological Seminary and Presbyterian School of Christian Education in Richmond, Virginia. Smylie was the editor of the Journal of Presbyterian History from 1968-1996. He is the author of numerous articles and books on various topics related to religious history, including the history of the Presbyterian Church, Christian experience in American, religion and politics, and the Roman Catholic Church in America. His books include Into All the World and A Cloud of Witnesses.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of James Smylie. Materials include: typescript manuscripts of articles; reprints and clippings of articles; pencil sketches of individuals associated with the Presbyterian Historical Society, 1979-1986; correspondence and manuscripts from Smylie's time as editor of the American Presbyterians Journal; newspaper and magazine clippings; photographs and negatives; and photostats of correspondence of Dr. Brown, from the archives at the Presbyterian Historical Society. Smylie manuscripts include: "Hanover Presbytery: Between Revolution and Civil War," "Lynching, 'The Black Christ,' and the Atonement," "William McGuffey, Eclectic Readers, and Virtuous Citizens," and "Thanks for the Memories," an address given at the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), Richmond, Virginia, 2004.
